report_title: Industry Report on Dried Fruit and Vegetable Snack Producers
executive_summary: Dried fruit and vegetable snack producers benefited from consistent consumer demand and a growing emphasis to stay healthy, with customers incorporating dried fruits and vegetables to be consumed as snacks or as ingredients in other food products such as granola bars, baked goods and salads. Over the past five years, producers also benefited from improving economic conditions, prior to COVID-19. Operators have grown steadily as consumers have increasingly sought out healthier alternatives to traditional salty snacks. While operators' goods are more expensive than traditional snacks, as discretionary income grew, renewed consumer spending helped boost sales for fruit bars, vegetable chips and other mixed snack foods that include dried fruit and vegetables. These trends caused revenue to grow at a CAGR of 2.0% to an estimated $5.2 billion through the end of 2023, including an anticipated 5.3% spike in 2023 alone due to continuing consumer trends.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consistent Consumer Demand Boosts Revenue Growth, Even as Economic Conditions Became Volatile
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite volatility stemming from COVID-19 and high inflationary pressures, dried fruit and vegetable snack producers have benefited from a strong demand boost among consumers and favorable economic trends. Even as economic conditions endured significant volatility during COVID-19, operators' production output continued to pick up pace, as consumers shifted their propensity toward healthier snacks that have less calories and sodium. Strong growth in disposable income during the pandemic also benefited operators, since dried fruit and vegetable snacks are considered a premium snack due to their higher cost of production; as inflation has spiked, a drop in disposable income was offset by spikes in commodity prices.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Health-Conscious Snacking Benefits Core Revenue Channels for Operators
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A crucial factor that has bolstered operators' revenue growth is the push toward healthier eating, which has incentivized consumers to cut extra calories and sodium from their diets while pursuing healthier snacking alternatives. Dried fruits and vegetables have many similar qualities and characteristics to traditional fruits and vegetables, while also carrying unique flavors that appeal to health-conscious consumers; as operators continue to innovate their product stream, it appeals to a larger customer base.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatility in Global Trade Markets Affects Snack Procurement Strategies
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Dried fruit and vegetable snack producers rely on commodities such as fruits and vegetables to ensure they meet domestic demand and expand within international markets, adding emphasis to global trade conditions. As supply chains have endured significant volatility during COVID-19, prices of fruits and vegetables have spiked; although this did curtail profitability for operators, it actually benefited revenue growth, as producers can pass on these costs to downstream customers. Since the production costs of operators' products have spiked, operators continue to look beyond domestic production and import a higher range of goods, with growth in the Trade-Weighted Index exemplifying this trend.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic Recovery Following Period of High Inflation Will Boost Operators' Growth Prospects
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As economic conditions continue to stabilize following a period of high inflation, dried fruit and vegetable snack producers will benefit from renewed consumer interest, as these snacks are high-premium alternatives to traditional snacking options. Anticipated growth in disposable income over the next five years will provide consumers with more capital to pursue more snack foods that have higher premium prices and organic products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Push Toward Healthier Eating Will Continue to Provide Consistent Demand Within Core Revenue Streams
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With healthy activities and health monitoring a major priority for consumers following COVID-19, healthy eating habits will continue to drive health-conscious consumers toward healthier snack alternatives from operators. As the healthy eating index is poised to inch upward over the next five years, operators will benefit from niche demand streams among customers eager to diversify their snack catalog and cut down on calories.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Growing Appeal of Foreign Markets Will Influence Core Consumer Markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Dried fruit and vegetable snack producers continue to benefit from strong domestic demand, although the cost of doing business domestically will change, as exemplified by a falling US Dollar and growing international marketplace. As more foreign markets continue to enter the marketplace, it will incentivize domestic operators to shift away from domestic production in exchange for foreign customers and larger supermarkets to offset a weaker dollar.

industry_definition: Dried fruit and vegetable manufacturers dehydrate and package purchased produce. These products are typically eaten by consumers as snacks or used as ingredients in salads and other meals.

threats: Per capita fruit and vegetable consumption

key_trends: Producing high-quality snacks enhances internal competition.
Consistent appeal of fresh fruits and vegetables strengthens external competition.
The strong popularity of healthy eating boosts demand for dried fruit and vegetable snacks.
Continued growth in disposable income will enable customers to buy dried fruit and vegetable snacks.
Steady growth in disposable income boosts consumers' fiscal capabilities
Consistent regulatory landscape creates steady compliance costs
A sharp incline in inflation eats away at profit
Emphasis on raw fruits and vegetables ensures high purchase costs
Proximity to commodity producers boosts establishment presence
Warm climate and geographic conditions benefit snack producers' production capabilities
Diversified usage strengthens the popularity of raisins
Widespread consumer usage boosts demand among grocery wholesalers

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment generates revenue within grocery wholesalers, whose function is to distribute operators' products to supermarkets and convenience stores, while also wholesaling direct to manufacturers. A significant chunk of customers purchases their snacks from local supermarkets and convenience stores, particularly since the prices of operators' products are higher than traditional snacks. As consumers continue to shift their tendencies toward healthier snacking options, grocery wholesalers that connect with the local client base will continue to benefit from heightened consumer demand.

This market segment generates revenue within retail stores. Major retailers are continuing to expand their connections with manufacturers, as dried fruit and vegetable snacks gain in popularity following COVID-19. Since more capital is required to set up a consistent contract with retailers, they make up a smaller, more niche operational base, primarily in larger cities.

This market segment generates revenue from mass merchandisers, such as Costco and Wal-Mart, foodservice areas like restaurants and cafes and alternative food producers that produce popular snacks like granola bars. Mass merchandisers and other carriers of operators' products have the ability to purchase a larger quantity of items via bulk orders at lower prices, which enables them to sell products at a lower cost for customers. As economic conditions continue to recover following high inflation and customers continue to pursue healthy snacking options, larger merchandisers will look to procure operators' products at a larger rate.

products_and_services.product_description: This product segment generates revenue from the sale of raisins, which are dried grapes that can be added into other products like granola bars and cereal or can be eaten on their own. Although raisins have a high level of sugar, they are full of nutritious fibers, vitamin B and iron, which makes it a popular snack item for health-conscious consumers. As the popularity of healthier snacks continues to rise and consumers' disposable income remains on the incline following high inflation, raisins will continue to generate the largest revenue stream for operators.

This product segment generates revenue from the sales of prunes, which are dried plums that are often packaged individually and can be eaten individually or in coordination with other foods. Dried prunes are primarily purchased by grocery wholesalers and retailers, as they have significantly larger access to a wider customer base that shops more frequently for these types of healthy snacks. Although prunes are considered very healthy for digestion and have higher popularity among older customers, they're more expensive, with high inflation eating away at core demand streams for operators.

This product segment generates revenue from the sales of all dried and dehydrated vegetables, such as potatoes, peppers and tomatoes. Many of these vegetables can be dried and used as ingredients in spices and cooking recipes used by foodservice providers and individual consumers. With consumers continuing to emphasize healthier eating habits following COVID-19, dried and dehydrated vegetables present a healthy alternative to traditional snacks.

This product segment generates revenue from the sale of dried apples. Dried apples have a wide range of utilities, as they can be used as pre-packaged slices for consumption and as ingredients in larger foods like salads and trail mixes. Many consumers have adopted eating gummy-like slices of dried apples, with apple chips another popular version of this product.

products_and_services.product_or_service: All other dried and dehydrated fruits, fruit peels and berries
products_and_services.product_description: Two segments that generate niche revenue for operators include sales of all other dried and dehydrated fruits and fruit peels and dried berries. Most consumers use dried and dehydrated fruits and fruit peels beyond the traditional snack, with some users using it in aromatic scents and candle-making while other use it as snacks. Dried berries continue to be a niche alternative to traditional snacks, with dried cranberries the most popular berry type used in salads and cooked dishes.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: When consumers possess more disposable income, they tend to make more discretionary purchases of higher cost food items like dried fruits and vegetables.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Per Capita Fruit and Vegetable Consumption
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As people consume more fruits and vegetables, demand for dried fruits and vegetables heightens.
A rise in fruit prices increases operators' costs, which can be passed on to consumers as higher prices.
Growth in the healthy eating index, measuring adherence to recommended diets, represents a shift toward healthier snacks like dried fruits and vegetables, benefiting operators.
A rise in vegetable prices increases operators' costs, which can then be passed on to consumers as higher prices.
An appreciation of the US dollar makes domestic goods relatively more expensive, tending to lead to higher imports and lower exports of operators' products.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Strong US Dollar Strengthens Import Appeal
international_trade_points.trade_description: The strong performance of the US dollar has boosted domestic producers' purchasing power for imports, despite supply chain issues.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Spike in Input Prices Strengthens Import Demand
international_trade_points.trade_description: Volatility in supply chains caused spikes in fruit and vegetable prices, so operators import to source less expensive commodities.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Diversified Offering Across Markets Establishes Export Patterns
international_trade_points.trade_description: Different countries specialize in certain commodities, creating unique export opportunities for operators across markets.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Free Trade Expansion Boosts Export Prospects
international_trade_points.trade_description: Policies like the USMCA make it easier to establish production contracts and ship products to neighboring countries.

business_locations.location_description: Favorable climate and geographic conditions boost establishment demand in the West. Dried fruit and vegetable snack producers are heavily dependent on consistently warm climate and geographic conditions to meet wholesaler and retailer demand, with the Western region housing the best of both worlds. In states like California, establishments benefit from consistently warm climates and a robust population presence of larger retailers and wholesalers that provide access to a variety of customers.

Strong saturation of retailers and mass merchandisers benefits establishments in the Great Lakes. Although the Great Lakes have considerably lower temperatures compared with the Western region, they have a significant chunk of retailers.

Robust crop production facilities enhance establishment presence in the Rocky Mountains. Although the Rocky Mountains lacks the population presence of other regions, it does house a considerable number of production facilities for core commodities, such as apples and potatoes.

Booming population presence strengthens demand in the Mid-Atlantic. Most demand generated within the Mid-Atlantic is predicated on strong consumer presence and proximity to core suppliers for operators' goods.
Additional markets that are under the radar. Some of the other regions with a significantly lower establishment presence include the Southwest, Southeast, Plains and the New England regions.
Additional markets that are under the radar. Some of the other regions with a significantly lower establishment presence include the Southwest, Southeast, Plains and the New England regions.
Additional markets that are under the radar. Some of the other regions with a significantly lower establishment presence include the Southwest, Southeast, Plains and the New England regions.
Additional markets that are under the radar. Some of the other regions with a significantly lower establishment presence include the Southwest, Southeast, Plains and the New England regions.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Department of Labor oversees the regulation regarding employee treatment and compensation, while the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) monitors the working conditions of employees to ensure all activities and materials are safe for employees.
The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulates the production process and the supply chain of food producers across the United States.
The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act requires most foods to have nutrition labeling.

Various federal environmental regulations and statutes directed from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) create stringent guidelines regarding how operators handle their products and dispose of waste.
To ensure worker safety during COVID-19, operators had to comply with sweeping health and safety regulations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: New operators face some regulatory barriers. Most regulations focus on food safety and inspections.
Start-up costs vary based on an operator's size and processing facilities.
There is strong differentiation across the industry.
Although new entrants require a consistent staff presence, there is a much higher capital intensity.

basis_points.basis_title: Producing high-quality snacks enhances internal competition
basis_points.basis_description: Operators that are able to produce high-quality and tasty snacks with a variety of flavors can attract new customers and gain an edge over their competitors.

basis_points.basis_title: Consistent appeal of fresh fruits and vegetables strengthens external competition
basis_points.basis_description: Traditional fruits and vegetables will remain a staple of consumers' diets.

concentration_points.concentration_title: LOCALIZED DEMAND FOR DRIED FRUIT AND VEGETABLE SNACKS DAMPENS MARKET CONCENTRATION
concentration_points.concentration_description: Dried fruit and vegetable snack producers are heavily reliant on specific climate conditions.

concentration_points.concentration_title: HIGH OPERATING COSTS LIMIT OPPORTUNITIES FOR EXPANSION
concentration_points.concentration_description: Operators face a variety of production costs that constrain profitability.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Emphasis on Quality Processing Enhances Administrative Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Most administrative expenses focus on ensuring adequate processing of orders.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Although new entrants require a consistent staff presence, there is a much higher capital intensity.

volatility_points.volatility_title: CONSISTENT DEMAND FOR DRIED FRUIT AND VEGETABLE SNACKS DAMPENS VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: Consumers' continuous interest in eating healthier snacks helps operators secure newfound demand for their products.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Strong Economic Recovery Stabilizes Core Revenue Streams
volatility_points.volatility_description: As more customers look to make the switch to healthy eating.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ACCELERATION IN TECHNOLOGICAL ADOPTION BOOSTS FRUIT AND VEGETABLE GATHERING EFFICIENCY
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The implementation of new technology has accelerated the organizational process.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries like China impacted your operations? How has the coronavirus pandemic affected import competition?
FAQs.answer: China and Chile account for close to one-third of imports.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or produce a diversified range of products? How has your product selection been affected by the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: This industry has many small companies that focus on one product.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years? How have you contended with additional volatility during the coronavirus pandemic and resulting supply chain disruptions?
FAQs.answer: Operators are heavily dependent on the price of raw fruits and vegetables.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Most operators own the farms that produce the raw fruits and vegetables used.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Systems for assembly aid in reducing manufacturing labor costs.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology in its operations?
FAQs.answer: Companies have switched to radio frequency identification (RFID) tags.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all relevant health and safety requirements are met? How have you ensured employee safety during the coronavirus pandemic?
FAQs.answer: The FDA closely monitors this industry.

FAQs.question: What effect have international tariffs had on your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Operators benefit from significant tariffs on dried fruit products originating from abroad.

FAQs.question: How has price volatility of inputs affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: The price of fruits and vegetables have both been volatile over the past five years.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover compare to major competitors?
FAQs.answer: Larger companies have contracts with national retailers.

FAQs.question: What quality control processes do you have in effect?
FAQs.answer: Operators have contracts with suppliers of key inputs to reduce supply volatility.

FAQs.question: Are you able to leverage economies of scale? What kind of scale does your business currently possess?
FAQs.answer: Economies of scale in production generate cost savings for dried fruit and vegetable producers.

FAQs.question: How is the water availability in your area? How does what availability affect your suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Water availability affects the quality of fruit and vegetable harvests.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising vegetable and fruit consumption?
FAQs.answer: Per capita fruit and vegetable consumption depends on several factors.

FAQs.question: How do price fluctuations of fruit affect your company?
FAQs.answer: Fruit is an essential input for dried fruit and other product processing.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels?
FAQs.answer: When consumers possess more disposable income, they usually make discretionary purchases.
